current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate
		  segments of the Missisquoi River and the Trout River in the State of Vermont,
		  as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Energy and Natural
			 Resources

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Upper Missisquoi and Trout Wild and
			 Scenic Rivers Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 3(a) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers
			 Act

header.#text:
Designation of
			 Wild and Scenic River Segments

Missisquoi
				River and Trout River, Vermont

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
as a
				recreational river:

text.#text:
The following segments in the
				State of Vermont, to be administered by the

The 20.5-mile
				segment of the Missisquoi River from the Lowell/Westfield town line to the
				Canadian border in North Troy, excluding the property and project boundary of
				the Troy and North Troy hydroelectric facilities.

The 14.6-mile
				segment of the Missisquoi River from the Canadian border in Richford to the
				upstream project boundary of the Enosburg Falls hydroelectric facility in
				Sampsonville.

The 11-mile
				segment of the Trout River from the confluence of the Jay and Wade Brooks in
				Montgomery to where the Trout River joins the Missisquoi River in East
				Berkshire.
The river segments designated by

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be
			 managed in accordance with—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
paragraph (208) of
			 section 3(a) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act

Notwithstanding

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the Missisquoi and Trout Rivers
			 shall not be administered as part of the National Park System or be subject to
			 regulations that govern the National Park System.

text.#text:
In this subsection, the term “additional
			 segment” means the 3.8-mile segment of the Missisquoi River extending from the
			 confluence of the Burgess Branch and East Branch of the Missisquoi River in
			 Lowell to the Lowell/Westfield town line.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

			 recreational river if the
